summary: Gastric cancer is a malignant tumor of the stomach that develops in the lining of the stomach due to abnormal cell growth. Most cases are gastric carcinomas, with subtypes including gastric adenocarcinomas. Lymphomas and mesenchymal tumors can also occur in the stomach. The cancer can spread to other parts of the body, including the liver, lungs, bones, lining of the abdomen, and lymph nodes. It is the fifth-leading type of cancer globally and the third-leading cause of cancer death.
risk_factors: Dietary factors (pickled vegetables, fried foods, smoked foods, salt-rich foods, meat, processed meat, red meat)
symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes
Bloating of the stomach after meals
diagnosis: Computed tomography (CT) scanning of the abdomen
Blood tests for tumor markers (carcinoembryonic antigen, carbohydrate antigen)
treatments: Surgery (gastrectomy, endoscopic mucosal resection, endoscopic submucosal dissection)
Chemotherapy (e.g., 5-fluorouracil, cisplatin, epirubicin, etoposide, docetaxel, oxaliplatin, capecitabine, irinotecan)
Targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab for HER2-overexpressing tumors)
subtypes: Extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphomas (MALT type)
